Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Further development of the HAOPs water treatment process for membrane pretreatment and phosphorus recovery from wastewater
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project results from the advancement of a novel water treatment process that reduces membrane fouling and significantly lowers water treatment costs. Membrane filtration is one of the primary water treatment technologies to address the global challenge of water scarcity. However, the membrane industry suffers from low productivity and high operational cost caused by fouling. Over 95% of the water treatment plants in US that employ membrane filtration currently operate at only 30-50% of their design capacity. Our revolutionary pretreatment technology not only mitigates fouling, but also increases system productivity by up to 400% and decreases the required membrane cleaning frequency by a factor of 50, thereby saving water, money and energy. The process can reduce both the capital expense and annual operational cost of water treatment plants by roughly 25%. Our innovation is also applicable to saline water, so it can be used as a pretreatment for desalination, and it can address another major environmental challenge by removing phosphorus from wastewater and thereby reducing the prevalence of blooms of toxic algae.

This SBIR Phase II project will continue our scale-up and commercialization activities for our pretreatment technology to improve the performance of membranes in water treatment processes with respect to contaminant removal, process productivity, and energy efficiency, compared to existing technologies. The process relies on application of a proprietary particle in a novel reactor and has been demonstrated in our Phase I work. The objectives of the Phase II work are (1) scale-up and construction of larger treatment modules using commercially suitable materials and fabrication processes; (2) testing under more aggressive operational conditions; (3) improving particle production, delivery, and disposal processes; and (4) evaluating the particles' suitability as an economic approach to remove and recover phosphorus from wastewater. The economic analysis will also be updated using data collected in Phase II study. The effort will advance the technical readiness level (TRL) of our process to TRL6, while providing essential data for further development and credibility for marketing. On completion of Phase II, we expect to be prepared for deployment in small-scale commercial systems treating one million gallons per day, and for testing in larger systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The availability of high-quality water is diminishing worldwide, exacerbated by population growth, urbanization, and climate change. New, more efficient and cost-effective processes that purify contaminated water are needed everywhere from the most highly developed to the most impoverished countries in the world.

This Phase II NSF Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project was undertaken to continue development and commercialization of a novel water process that had been previously demonstrated in laboratory-scale testing. In this process, a thin layer of pollutant-collecting particles is loosely deposited on a porous support such as a mesh. Water containing dissolved pollutants and/or small particles is then passed through the layer, and both groups of contaminants are removed. Eventually, the capacity of the layer to collect the contaminants is exhausted, at which point a quick reverse flow of water and air washes both the deposited particles and pollutants out of the system, and the whole process is re-initiated.

In early tests of our process, newly invented particles that we refer to as ?HAOPs? (short for Heated Aluminum Oxide Particles) were used to form the beneficial layer. HAOPs were developed to remove organic pollutants that clog membranes in water treatment systems, so by removing those pollutants early in the treatment process, the performance of the membranes can be greatly improved. Subsequently, it was determined that HAOPs could also efficiently remove phosphorus from domestic wastewater and thereby greatly reduce the likelihood that the wastewater would cause harmful algal blooms to develop when the wastewater is discharged to a lake or river. In addition, preliminary results have indicated that the novel reactor type could work with layers composed of other particles that target different contaminants, thereby extending its applicability to numerous other situations.

The current project demonstrated that the new technology could be implemented successfully to treat flow rates approximately 100 times larger than were tested in Phase I for removal of both the organic contaminants that plug membranes and phosphorus in wastewater. Specific accomplishments included:

  • Re-design of key components of the hardware used in the novel process to make them practical for use at commercial scale;
  • Operational modifications that allow water to be treated at higher flow rates during the treatment step and decrease the amount of water used during the system cleaning steps;
  • Demonstration of the technology onsite at one drinking water treatment facility and two municipal wastewater treatment plants; and
  • Establishment of collaborative, locally funded testing projects in Norway, Singapore and China.

Thus, the project has advanced the technical and commercial readiness of our process, which we believe is now poised to move to a stage of final, full-scale testing and implementation.
